newsitem.title: NIGERIA: Absence of judge stalls Nigerian musician's trial.
newsitem.headline: Absence of judge stalls Nigerian musician's trial.

text.p: The absence on Monday of a judge prevented the trial in Nigeria of maverick musician Fela Anikulapo-Kuti on drug charges, witnesses said.
The tribunal's registrar did not give a reason for the absence of chairman Judge Yusuf Tanko Usman and adjourned the case to Wednesday.
Witnesses said many of Fela's fans thronged the venue, while a pale-looking Fela acknowledged their cheers.
Fela, as he is widely known, faces a minimum of 15 years in jail if convicted of possessing and using cannabis.
Fela, 59, was arrested on April 9 with 107 other people at his "The Shrine" nightclub in a working class district of Lagos for alleged possession of cannabis.
The National Drug Law Enforcement Agency (NDLEA) has since freed most of the others arrested with him.

Fela filed a suit last week at a Lagos court claiming 100 million naira ($11,765) in damages from the NDLEA for alleged violation of his human rights and a high court judge ordered that he should be released by the agency.
His lawyer Femi Falana, a human rights activist, said on Monday: "This tribunal is a law court and a high court has set Fela free, so the tribunal should obey the court order."
There is no bail for drug offences in Nigeria.

The Afro-beat superstar is no stranger to controversy -- or to the jail cell. A past critic of Nigeria's military rulers, he has a reputation for openly smoking marijuana and dressing only in his underpants.
